text.title: part4_Edmund White on writing, incest, life and Larry Kramer

p.hi: DS: Are you a slave or a master?

text.p: EW: A slave, but I’m not much of one.

p.hi: DS: Why are you a bad slave?

text.p: EW: I’m not into pain and it has to strike me just right or it starts to seem ridiculous.

p.hi: DS: At what point does it start to seem ridiculous?

text.p: EW: Too much leather, bad grammar on the part of the master! [Laughs]
EW: Like, “Lay down” instead of “Lie down.”
EW: I have dominated, it’s just not as pleasurable. When I was younger I had slaves, even for a whole year at a time.

p.hi: DS: You had a slave relationship.

text.p: EW: One day we were on acid down in Key West and I realized I didn’t even like him, so I broke up with him. I thought it was okay to be doing it if I actually like or love him, but if I really have contempt for him, that’s no good. It has to be an expression of love.

p.hi: DS: What psychological issues come out in a relationship like that?

text.p: EW: Unrequited feelings for love from your father, often times. Longings for passivity. A lot of people have that.

p.hi: DS: To give up the feeling they always have to be in control in their waking lives?

text.p: EW: I have a good friend who is a European novelist who was willing to literally hand over all of his belongings to this master, just signed over everything he owned to live in a cage the rest of his life. It turned out to be a fraud to fleece him of his money.

p.hi: DS: That must have been disappointing for him.

text.p: EW: It’s a good thing he discovered that in time, didn’t lose his money and didn’t live in a cage the rest of his life, because he’s actually a very interesting person with a very full life.

p.hi: DS: What psychological issues did you work through in your slave-master relationships?

text.p: EW: Different ones. If it’s not an on-going thing then you would get tired of it and drop it all together. It’s not a very major part of my life.

p.hi: DS: Did it used to be more so?

text.p: EW: Yes. But it was also a fresher scene back then. Now it feels like a very tired scene and I hate people in leather, I think that’s so stupid.

p.hi: DS: Like they are wearing Halloween costumes?
DS: As if the fashion never changes? It’s always the same chaps, the same harness…

text.p: EW: Yeah…yeah, that’s right. One of the interesting things about Robert Mapplethorpe—who was a friend of mine and I have quite a few pictures here by him, including two of me—he had leathers made for him in Amsterdam with red and blue piping, fitting in an interesting way with different kinds of leather. A patchwork effect without making it look silly. He was very elegant. They were attractive and sexy.
